segments.text: paralysis to the lower jaw.
That was the only symptom he had.
I buried him, and that night my brother, who was in Baylor Med School, came home from college, and we told him about the dog.
He dug the dog up, sent the head to Austin for examination, and proved that he had rabies.
So my father and my neighbor and I and my brother all had to take the Pasteur treatment, which consisted of 25 doses.
You've been through this?
Yes, I've been through it when I was a child.
And then during the rabies epidemic here in the cattle, I took the vaccine at least once a year for three years just to keep myself immunized.
If you have rabies, you die.
Now, tell me about the past year treatment that you're talking about for rabies in humans.
It's a series of 25 doses you said.
Well, I don't remember if it was 20 or 25, but it seemed like 25 the first time I took it.
But it's been perfected now and people can be immunized.
Most veterinarians take a dose of rabies vaccine annually just to keep them immunized.
But if you get bit by an animal that has rabies, then you have to take a series of vaccines hoping that you will be protected and not die.
I lost a classmate who graduated when I did
He was bitten by a dog back in the 1940s, and even though he took the treatment, he developed rabies and died.
So I've always had a respect for it.
Yes, you hear that the vaccines are administered, you know, I don't know whether this is true or not, in the stomach.
Is that true?
No, they're administered in the muscle of the abdomen.
Muscle of the abdomen.
Abdominal muscle.
Okay.
People get mixed up when they're talking about the stomach and the abdominal muscles.
They use a short needle going into the muscle of the abdomen.
And you've had these treatments?
And you can take them in your arms.
I took them in my arms usually after I became an adult.
Mm-hmm.
but uh... so you've been through this so-called painful treatment of rabies as young as eight years old
Oh, yes.
Eight or ten.
I can't remember exactly when it was, but I was a child.
But I was interested in treating all the sick animals in the neighborhood.
The type of rabies you just described, as early as you say, was called dumb rabies, where the paralysis of the lower jaw, the jaw fell down, the tongue hung out.
But there's also the other type of rabies that everybody recognizes, the foaming of the mouth.
And leaving home.
Roaming.
The most dangerous type of rabies is the dumb rabies because people don't recognize it.
If a cow has dumb rabies, she just stands around and slobbers and drools saliva and people think she has a corncob hung across the roof of her mouth and they examine her and expose themselves.
That happened to one man and he had to take the rabies shots and it made him sick.
Physically sick.
He had to be in bed for a month or two.
I knew two people in Henderson who had that problem.
Some people do have reactions to the vaccine, but 99% of them fully recover after a month or two.
So you still need to take the vaccine if you expose yourself.
Right.
Okay, so that's something I've learned about rabies this morning, no doubt about that.
May I mention oak buds and acorn poisoning?
Do we have time?
Sure.
That is something that we still see.
Oak buds poison cattle, especially in early spring.
If you're not feeding them enough and they start eating oak buds.
I saw the first herd affected.
Again, it was Ralph Ballinger's caves out north of Henderson.
I've also seen people cut timber in spring and summer and the cattle have...
perhaps not quite as much grass as they want, so they go out there and eat all of the oak leaves on these trees.
And they can get down and die.
Mary Kelly lost four or five cows one year when she was selling oak timber.
So you must be careful that you don't let your cattle eat too many oak leaves
Oak buds in the spring are too many acorns.
In the fall of the year, if you turn your cattle into a pasture with a lot of acorns on the ground and they get started eating them, it seems like that they like acorns.
And if you don't feed them hay and get them off of those acorns, if they stay in a woods pasture and eat too many acorns for a week, you can lose them.
I saw that happen to several people.
So that's something that is ever-present danger.
Right.
If you could, I know that veterinary medicine has sort of a lot of things...
pre-World War II era and a post-World War II era, and that came with the advent of the A&M Medical School, which had its first graduates in 1920 and, of course, was in the war a short 20 years later.
What about some of the remedies that were used before the war and after the war since there'd been a lot of, I'm sure, test run and research done?

some of the favorite old remedies that many of us remember being used when we were children and up until the world war two era we might say were for hollow tail which was now these remedies were used in cattle hollow tail was a common uh... condition that was being diagnosed by people who
didn't know what was wrong with the cow.
They knew that she was down and couldn't get up.
She was paralyzed.
They would feel of her tail, find a soft spot due to a deficiency, and call it hollow tail.
They would split the tail and put something like salt and pepper or turpentine on it.
Then, of course, if they treated the cow properly with enough food and water, a few of them would live.
Another very common thing in treating a cow with

mineral deficiency we call milk fever was seen when a cow would have a calf and sometime maybe in 48 hours she would become down and unable to walk and go into a coma those cattle were commonly referred to as having milk fever even though they didn't have any fever the temperature would be below normal it was a misnomer and before the days of
graduate veterinarians who injected calcium gluconate solution into the vein to make the cow overcome the disease and get up and start walking off in 10 or 15 minutes.
The common treatment was pumping air into their udder.

And, of course, it would work because it would make the cow quit producing milk, and she would gradually get better, and most of them would survive but end up with a case of mastitis, infection up in the quarters.

And the loss of the cud, as people called it, when a cow got sick and quit chewing her cud, as most sick cows do, some people thought they would have to take an old dish rag and poke it down their throat to give them another cud, which, of course, some cows would die from that treatment.
Sounds like it.
And I saw many cows that were being treated with
with mistletoe that was being fed to them due to the cow that was retaining her afterbirth more than two or three days.
And of course they would get word and they'd start feeding her mistletoe.
What would the mistletoe do?
Would it help?
No, the mistletoe wouldn't help.
But if the cow didn't get an infection and die, and she passed the placenta or afterbirth in five or six days, then the mistletoe would get credit for curing her.
So it's just luck if it happened, huh?
Yes.
You just would have been feeding them anything, huh?
Anything.
And most of them will, of course, if you're lucky.
survive, but they don't all pass their afterbirth in 48 hours.
It depends on the nutrition that the cow's receiving as much as anything.

Then on horses and mules, a very common thing that we saw was colic, commonly called blocked kidneys, and people were commonly using turpentine or kerosene and a saucer held to the navel of the cow, and if that
the horse or mule.

If it would be absorbed then they thought it would probably work and it would work in the fact that you'd get up and start leading the horse around and those that had gas colic would start passing the gas and recover.
Then there were several other things that were being used for worms in horses
If they looked wormy, they'd feed them a plug of tobacco.
And that did kill a few of the worms.
Blind stagers, which was the common name for sleeping sickness or encephalomyelitis, people would split the skin on the forehead and insert a dime.
And of course, I don't think any of them ever lived, but they would get treated.
Then fistula of the withers, which was a disease that some of us remember.
and still see one occasionally.
They would drain the abscess, which occurred on the upper part of the shoulder blade, drain the abscess, and insert several coins to help keep it draining.
Fish of the weathers, of course, could be treated in other ways, and we cured some of them.
But it was always a long, drawn-out treatment.
And the dogs that would have distemper
The most common treatment was to soak three or four small corn cobs in a mixture of Vicksave and turpentine and string it on a wire or a cord and use it as a collar on these dogs.
Of course, some dogs with distemper always recover, regardless of what you do, if they don't develop pneumonia or encephalitis.
These were some of the treatments that were sort of homespun, I guess you would call it, and you can't give much credit to, I guess, any one of them as being particularly helpful.
Kind of nature took its course one way or the other, but I guess human beings had to act in some way or another, didn't they?
But what are some of the big changes you've seen in the veterinary medicine since World War II?
Since World War II, the changes that I have noticed...

would be the building of modern veterinary hospitals for treating and hospitalizing animals in most counties of Texas, bone surgery for fractures in pets and domestic livestock, abdominal surgery such as C-sections, tumor surgery, and surgery for horses that have colic with twisted intestines, x-rays,
are commonly used now in the diagnosis of diseases in animals.
And very extensive laboratory tests are made to diagnose and treat animals.
And in some areas you have embryo transplants in cattle and horses, which is a big business.
There they take the embryo from the valuable registered animal and transplant it into the non-registered sheep
cow or horse, mare, and grow the registered coat.
The surgery for herniated discs in vertebrae of dogs and cats is very common.
The new vaccines and new drugs for preventing and treating diseases that are available is a revolutionary change.
You've seen a lot of them happen and experienced most of the diseases, I guess, here in Russ County.
What are some of the diseases that were taken care of by veterinary medicine over the years that we don't have a problem with now?
Well, the most common diseases that I recall being eradicated completely would be the Texas tick fever by dipping the cattle.
And that was eradicated in the 30s.
hoof and mouth disease by slaughtering all the infected herds.
When I moved here in 47, a veterinarian who had been ahead of me left Henderson and went to Mexico to help the Mexican government.
The hog cholera, which all of our older people remember was so common, has been completely eradicated.
The loin disease and creeps
that we mentioned earlier, by using minerals in their feeds, has been eradicated.
The X disease that we mentioned has been eradicated.
Vesicular exanthema in swine was a disease that caused ulcers on the nose and mouth of hogs.
I only saw one case.
I was called by a man who had bought a hog at the auction barn, and after he bought her, he noticed it.
He carried her onto his farm, even though I told him that it looked like it might be vesicular exanthema, a new disease that had just been described in the newspapers.
Well, he took her onto his farm and exposed his herd.
And then two weeks later, he called me and told me what he had done.

And we had to call the state veterinarian who came up here and killed most of his hogs to eradicate the vesicular exanthema, which is similar in clinical symptoms, similar to the foot and mouth disease or hoof and mouth disease in cattle, which was eradicated.
Our guest this morning, Dr. Hugh M. Phillips, retired doctor of veterinary medicine practice, 38 years here in Henderson from 1947 until 1985.

And as I said, we've been running over on the roadshow a little bit this morning, but my goodness, we've got Dr. Phillips here, and we're taping this for the book that's going to be coming out, and the title of the book will be The History of Veterinary Medicine Today.
in Texas, and we've covered it statewide.
We've also covered it countywide and how Dr. Phillips came to be here and he and his family in the Henderson area.

We've, of course, gotten some phone calls over the past hour and 20 minutes or so, which I'm sure that you'll be able to refer to these Dr. Phillips from Henderson and Russ County, people involved in A&M.
Mr. Milner, who was president, you might want to address that in just a minute.

Well, Mr. Milner, of course, was one of the presidents, and he not only lived on the A&M campus, and I lived in a dormitory called Milner Dorm one year, but he lived here in Henderson in what we used to call the Milner Addition out where the Baptist College is now located.
We also had Mr. Gathright, who was a president of A&M.
He's buried here.
Milner
And Gathrider both buried here in the Old City Cemetery.
Okay.
And let's see, there's a teacher down at A&M from the area, I believe, Mr. Anderson?
Dr. Anderson.
Right.
Dr. Jim Anderson, the son of Mr. Gilbert Anderson, who used to be the Three Bell Brothers manager, is one of our best teachers at A&M in the Department of Physiology.
He's still there, right?
He's still there.
I visited with him about a month ago when I was at A&M.
Any other Rusconians or East Texans you recall involved in the vet college?
Well, we had one veterinarian here who stayed about two months.
And Dr. James Denton, he also rented the building from Mr. Brown.
And he was ahead of me, immediately ahead of me.
I followed him.
He fell in love with a girl from Dallas.
and decided to get married, and they moved out to Cisco, Texas, and had three little boys.
And Cisco was nothing to compare to Henderson in size or in industry.
So after being there and having three little boys and getting hungry, he moved and went down to teach at A&M.
He became an excellent teacher in large animal clinics at A&M.
And I've teased him many times about leaving Henderson and going to Cisco out west Texas.
Right, I believe it's this side Abilene.
Yes.
I don't know why he chose Cisco.
I've forgotten.
Over there by Eastland and in that area.
Yeah, that's way out there.
Well, Dr. Phillips, we've covered a lot this morning, the history of veterinary medicine in Texas, also history of veterinary medicine in Russ County.
Any other things that come to mind right now while we're here?
Something interesting I wanted to mention is a conversation I had with Mr. Pete Smith.
And at that time, he told me that his brother, Virgil Smith, was one of the tick inspectors.
And back in the early 1930s, Virgil Smith, most of you remember, owned Auction Barn, was one of the owners, was working for the state as a tick inspector.
they were making seventy five dollars a month furnishing his own horse also uh... mister gordon brown who was sheriff here in the early fifties was a tick inspector and of course
Back in those days, a lot of the people didn't want to dip their cattle.
A few of them refused, and they would have to be forced by the sheriff to dip their cattle.
And Shelby County and Houston County were noted for having more trouble.
One man was killed in Shelby County, and I remember Pete Smith told me that his brother, Virgil Smith, when he was transferred from here to Houston County,
Down there they let him carry a pistol with him for protection because many of the people decided they would not dip the old milk cow.
People get attached to the old boss, you know, bossy or whatever they called her, and didn't want her dipped.
So in order to eradicate the ticks and the disease,
People were forced to dip their cattle, whether they wanted to or not.
I thought that would be interesting.
Some of the people who worked as tick inspectors that we know.
Turned out to be a dangerous job in one case there.
It did.
Dr. Hugh M. Phillips, our guest this morning, retired doctor of veterinary medicine.
And let's see, you, I was trying to go back through my notes here.
You graduated what year from the veterinary, 43?
1943, I went into the Army.
Okay.
Okay.
So you practiced until 1985 and practiced here in Henderson for 38 years since 1947.

Gosh, we've had a marathon this morning, but I believe this was very necessary in the recording of the research you've done, not only for the state of Texas as a whole, but for our East Texas area and experience from your 38-year career here in Russ County.
Dr. Phillips, we again appreciate you very much this morning putting up with us and going through this entire history with us.
We appreciate it.
Thank you, Chipper.
Veterinary medicine is close to my heart, and I enjoy doing anything that helps people.
Right.
Thank you very much, sir.
Okay, that's going to be it for the road show this morning.
We do have a full week for you for the rest of the week, too.
Let me remind you that tomorrow morning we're going to be talking with the Noon Lion.
